Description: Body sherd of South Ionian pottery cup, presumably with everted rim; interior glazed black with trace of added red line at top of sherd; exterior reserved; inscription on exterior.
Type series: Vallet and Villard Ionian Cup Type B1
Curator's comments: Although Shclotzhauer does not discuss this sherd, it finds parallels with British Museun 1888,0601.426 which Schlotzhauer identifies as coming from a Type 10.2Ag South Ionian cup with everted rim. Type 10 cups were mass produced and include numerous variants. These cups coincide with Hayes’ Ionian Cup Type V (Boardman and Hayes 1966, 111-116) and Vallet and Villard’s Ionian Cup Type B1 (Vallet and Villard, 1964, 87-88). Numerous Type 10 South Ionian cups have been found at Naukratis, as well as in the Sanctuary of Demeter and Kore at Tocra and at Megara Hyblaea on Sicily, and at Berezan on the Black Sea (Posamentir 2006, 165). The place of production of the vase was determined as probably Miletus based on the results of NAA analysis carried out by Hans Mommsen, Bonn, on another sherd (British Museum 1886,0401.1025) from Naukratis and of same shape, decoration, and fabric.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GE.684) (Phase 3)
